concepts.evidence_quote: Which ten dhammas should be realized? Ten qualities of one beyond training: the right view of one beyond training, the right resolve of one beyond training, the right speech of one beyond training, the right action of one beyond training, the right livelihood of one beyond training, the right effort of one beyond training, the right mindfulness of one beyond training, the right concentration of one beyond training, the right knowledge of one beyond training, the right release of one beyond training. These ten dhammas should be realized.
Phenomena are preceded by the heart, ruled by the heart, made of the heart.
Phenomena are preceded by the heart, ruled by the heart, made of the heart.
If you speak or act with a corrupted heart, then suffering follows you
then suffering follows you
If you speak or act with a calm, bright heart, then happiness follows you
then happiness follows you
hostility isn’t stilled.
Hostilities are stilled through non-hostility
this, an unending truth.
that we’re here on the verge of perishing
their quarrels are stilled.
One who stays focused on the beautiful
is unrestrained with the senses
knowing no moderation in food
apathetic
unenergetic
Mara overcomes him
One who stays focused on the foul
is restrained with regard to the senses
knowing moderation in food
full of conviction
& energy
He who, depraved,
devoid of truthfulness
devoid of truthfulness & self-control
puts on the ochre robe
endowed with truthfulness
endowed with truthfulness & self-control
well-established in the precepts
Those who regard non-essence as essence
and see essence as non-
ranging about in wrong resolves.
ranging about in right resolves.
so passion,
the undeveloped mind.
the well-developed mind.
he grieves he grieves hereafter.
In both worlds the wrong-doer grieves.
seeing the corruption of his deeds.
he rejoices he rejoices hereafter.
In both worlds the merit-maker rejoices.
seeing the purity of his deeds.
he’s tormented he’s tormented hereafter.
Having gone to a bad destination,
he delights he delights hereafter.
Having gone to a good destination,
If he recites many teachings
–heedless man–
he has no share in the contemplative life.
but follows the Dhamma in line with the Dhamma;
abandoning passion,
aversion,
delusion;
alert,
his mind well released,
not clinging
Heedfulness: the path to the Deathless.
Heedfulness: the path to the Deathless.
Heedlessness: the path to death.
Heedlessness: the path to death.
The heedful do not die.
The heedless are as if already dead.
Knowing this as a true distinction, those wise in heedfulness rejoice in heedfulness, enjoying the range of the noble ones.
enjoying the range of the noble ones.
The enlightened, constantly absorbed in jhana, persevering, firm in their effort: they touch Unbinding, the unexcelled rest from the yoke.
The enlightened, constantly absorbed in jhana,
they touch Unbinding, the unexcelled rest from the yoke.
the unexcelled rest from the yoke.
Those with initiative, mindful, clean in action, acting with due consideration, heedful, restrained, living the Dhamma: their glory grows.
mindful, clean in action,
heedful, restrained,
living the Dhamma:
Through initiative, heedfulness, restraint, & self-control, the wise would make an island no flood can submerge.
the wise would make an island no flood can submerge.
no flood can submerge.
They’re addicted to heedlessness –dullards, fools–
They’re addicted to heedlessness –dullards, fools–
or to intimacy with sensual delight–
for a heedful person, absorbed in jhana, attains an abundance of ease.
attains an abundance of ease.
having climbed the high tower of discernment,
sorrow-free,
he observes the sorrowing crowd–
as the enlightened man, having scaled a summit,
wakeful among those asleep,
wakeful among those asleep,
leaving the weak behind:
Through heedfulness, Indra won to lordship over the devas.
lordship over the devas.
The monk delighting in heedfulness, seeing danger in heedlessness, advances like a fire, burning fetters great & small.
seeing danger in heedlessness,
burning fetters great & small.
Quivering, wavering, hard to guard, to hold in check: the mind.
The sage makes it straight– like a fletcher, the shaft of an arrow.
like a fletcher, the shaft of an arrow.
the shaft of an arrow.
to escape Mara’s sway.
to escape Mara’s sway.
Its taming is good. The mind well-tamed brings ease.
The mind well-tamed brings ease.
The wise should guard it.
The wise should guard it. The mind protected brings ease.
Those who restrain it: from Mara’s bonds they’ll be freed.
from Mara’s bonds they’ll be freed.
For a person of unsteady mind, not knowing true Dhamma, serenity set adrift: discernment doesn’t grow full.
not knowing true Dhamma,
serenity set adrift:
discernment doesn’t grow full.
For a person of unsoddened mind,
unassaulted awareness,
abandoning merit & evil,
wakeful,
there is no danger no fear.
no danger no fear.
Knowing this body is like a clay jar,
is like a clay jar,
securing this mind like a fort,
like a fort,
attack Mara with the spear of discernment,
with the spear of discernment,
then guard what’s won
without settling there,
without laying claim.
bereft of consciousness,
like a useless scrap of wood.
Whatever an enemy might do to an enemy,
or a foe to a foe,
the ill-directed mind can do to you even worse.
Whatever a mother, father or other kinsman might do for you,
Whatever a mother, father or other kinsman might do for you,
or other kinsman might do for you,
the well-directed mind can do for you even better.
Who will penetrate this earth
& this realm of death
with all its gods?
Who will ferret out the well-taught Dhamma-saying,
as the skillful flower-arranger the flower?
The learner-on-the-path will penetrate this earth
Knowing this body is like foam, realizing its nature –a mirage–
cutting out the blossoms of Mara,
cutting out the blossoms of Mara,
where the King of Death can’t see.
The man immersed in gathering blossoms, his heart distracted:
his heart distracted:
death sweeps him away–
insatiable in sensual pleasures:
the End-Maker holds him under his sway.
As a bee–without harming the blossom, its color, its fragrance– takes its nectar & flies away:
so should the sage go through a village.
so should the sage go through a village.
not on the rudenesses of others,
not on what they’ve done or left undone,
but on what you have & haven’t done yourself.
Just like a blossom, bright colored but scentless:
a well-spoken word is fruitless when not carried out.
many garland strands can be made,
even so one born & mortal should do –with what’s born & is mortal– many a skillful thing.
many a skillful thing.
No flower’s scent goes against the wind–
not sandalwood,
jasmine,
tagara.
But the scent of the good does go against the wind.
The person of integrity wafts a scent in every direction.
among these scents, the scent of virtue is unsurpassed.
the scent of virtue is unsurpassed.
while the scent of virtuous conduct wafts to the devas, supreme.
wafts to the devas, supreme.
Those consummate in virtue,
dwelling in heedfulness,
released through right knowing:
As in a pile of rubbish cast by the side of a highway
cast by the side of a highway
a lotus might grow clean-smelling pleasing the heart,
there dazzles with discernment the disciple of the Rightly Self-Awakened One.

concepts.concept_name: Disciple of the Rightly Self-Awakened One
concepts.evidence_quote: the disciple of the Rightly Self-Awakened One.
the Rightly Self-Awakened One.
people run-of-the-mill & blind,
Long for the wakeful is the night.
Long for the weary, a league.
For fools unaware of True Dhamma, samsara is long.
For fools unaware of True Dhamma, samsara is long.
samsara is long.
If, in your course, you don’t meet your equal, your better,
If, in your course, you don’t meet your equal, your better,
There’s no fellowship with fools.
‘I have sons, I have wealth’–the fool torments himself.
‘I have sons, I have wealth’–the fool torments himself.
When even he himself doesn’t belong to himself, how then sons? How wealth?
A fool with a sense of his foolishness is–at least to that extent–wise.
A fool with a sense of his foolishness is–at least to that extent–wise.
Even if for a moment, the perceptive person stays with the wise, he immediately knows the Dhamma–as the tongue, the taste of the soup.
he knows nothing of the Dhamma–as the ladle, the taste of the soup.
Fools, their wisdom weak, are their own enemies as they go through life, doing evil that bears bitter fruit.
Fools, their wisdom weak, are their own enemies as they go through life,
doing evil that bears bitter fruit.
doing evil that bears bitter fruit.
It’s not good, the doing of the deed that, once it’s done, you regret,
that, once it’s done, you regret,
whose result you reap crying, your face in tears.
whose result you reap crying, your face in tears.
whose result you reap gratified, happy at heart.
whose result you reap gratified, happy at heart.
As long as evil has yet to ripen, the fool mistakes it for honey.
As long as evil has yet to ripen, the fool mistakes it for honey.
But when that evil ripens, the fool falls into pain.
but he wouldn’t be worth one sixteenth of those who’ve fathomed the Dhamma.
An evil deed, when done, doesn’t–like ready milk–come out right away.
It follows the fool, smoldering like a fire hidden in ashes.
Only for his ruin does renown come to the fool.
Only for his ruin does renown come to the fool.
It ravages his bright fortune & rips his head apart.
He would want unwarranted status, preeminence among monks, authority among monasteries, homage from lay families.
preeminence among monks,
authority among monasteries,
homage from lay families.
‘Let householders & those gone forth both think that this was done by me alone.
‘Let householders & those gone forth both think that this was done by me alone.
May I alone determine what’s a duty, what’s not’:
the resolve of a fool as they grow–his desire & pride.
his desire & pride.
his desire & pride.
The path to material gain goes one way,
the way to Unbinding, another.
the way to Unbinding, another.
Realizing this, the monk, a disciple to the Awakened One, shouldn’t relish offerings, should cultivate seclusion instead.
a disciple to the Awakened One,
a disciple to the Awakened One,
shouldn’t relish offerings, should cultivate seclusion instead.
should cultivate seclusion instead.
Regard him as one who points out treasure, the wise one who seeing your faults rebukes you.
...seeing your faults rebukes you.
...rebukes you.

Let him admonish, instruct, deflect you away from poor manners.
Let him admonish, instruct, deflect you away from poor manners.

Drinking the Dhamma, refreshed by the Dhamma, one sleeps at ease with clear awareness & calm.

Drinking the Dhamma, refreshed by the Dhamma, one sleeps at ease with clear awareness & calm.

Irrigators guide the water.

Fletchers shape the arrow shaft.

Carpenters shape the wood.

...so the wise are not moved by praise, by blame.

They, the good, don’t chatter in hopes of favor or gains.
When touched now by pleasure, now pain, the wise give no sign of high or low.
When touched now by pleasure, now pain, the wise give no sign of high or low.
When touched now by pleasure, now pain, the wise give no sign of high or low.
...hanker for wealth, a son, a kingdom, his own fulfillment, by unrighteous means...
...hanker for wealth, a son, a kingdom, his own fulfillment, by unrighteous means...
...hanker for wealth, a son, a kingdom, his own fulfillment, by unrighteous means...
...hanker for wealth, a son, a kingdom, his own fulfillment, by unrighteous means...

...rich in virtue, discernment.

concepts.concept_name: One Who Has Gone the Full Distance
concepts.evidence_quote: In one who has gone the full distance, is free from sorrow, is everywhere fully released, has abandoned all bonds: no fever is found.

their pasture–emptiness & freedom without sign

for they’re not searching for sensual pleasures.

Many other English translations are already available–the fingers of at least five people would be needed to count them–so I suppose that a new translation has to be justified, to prove that it’s not “just” another one.
The original impulse for making the translation came from my conviction that the text deserved to be offered freely as a gift of Dhamma.

Instead, I’ll ask you to read the Introduction and Historical Notes, to gain an idea of what is distinctive about the approach I have taken, and the translation itself, which I hope will stand on its own merits.

Monks, these four things are next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless. Which four? Cast-off cloth is next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless. Alms food is next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless. The root of a tree as a dwelling place is next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless. Medicine made of smelly urine1 is next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless. These are the four things that are next to nothing, both easy to gain & blameless.

The nine abodes for beings [“Seven stations of consciousness and two dimensions: “There are beings with multiplicity of body and multiplicity of perception, such as human beings, some devas, and some beings in the lower realms. This is the first station of consciousness. “There are beings with multiplicity of body and singularity of perception, such as the devas of the Brahma hosts generated by the first (jhāna). This is the second station of consciousness. “There are beings with singularity of body and multiplicity of perception, such as the Radiant Devas. This is the third station of consciousness. “There are beings with singularity of body and singularity of perception, such as the Beautiful Black Devas. This is the fourth station of consciousness. “There are beings who, with the complete transcending of perceptions of [physical] form, with the disappearance of perceptions of resistance, and not heeding perceptions of multiplicity, [perceiving,] ‘Infinite space,’ arrive at the dimension of the infinitude of space. This is the fifth station of consciousness. “There are beings who, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of space, [perceiving,] ‘Infinite consciousness,’ arrive at the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness. This is the sixth station of consciousness. “There are beings who, with the complete transcending of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness, [perceiving,] ‘There is nothing,’ arrive at the dimension of nothingness. This is the seventh station of consciousness. “The dimension of non-percipient beings and, second, the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. These are the two dimensions.” {DN 15}]
Seven stations of consciousness and two dimensions:

concepts.concept_name: Actions That Make One an Outcaste
concepts.evidence_quote: But do you know, brahman, what an outcaste is, or the actions that make one an outcaste?”
No, in fact, Master Gotama, I don’t know what an outcaste is, or the actions that make one an outcaste.
It would be good if Master Gotama taught me the Dhamma so that I would know what an outcaste is and the actions that make one an outcaste.”
